entry.title: The Triangle Product and 3-Hypermatrices
entry.summary:
Lately I have been thinking a lot about linear algebra and matrices. Indeed, I have been thinking about higher-dimensional generalizations involving $(p \times q \times r)$-hypermatrices. This was triggered by reading this blog post on tensors. First, let me review the story of $d$-vectors and $(m \times n)$-matrices.

0-Hypermatrices

0-Hypermatrices are scalars. These objects carry no indices and can be represented by just a single (real or complex) number.

1-Hypermatrices

1-Hypermatrices are vectors. These objects carry one index and can be represented as linear arrays of numbers. A $d$-vector with real components is an element of $\mathbb{R}^{d}$.

2-Hypermatrices

2-Hypermatrices are traditional matrices. These objects carry two indices and can be represented as rectangular arrays of numbers. An $(m \times n)$-matrix with real components is an element of $\mathbb{R}^{m \times n}$.

You have the matrix multiplication operation $P_{1}$ that takes an $(m \times p)$-matrix and a $(p \times n)$-matrix, and returns an $(m \times n)$-matrix: $$P_{1}: \mathbb{R}^{m \times p} \otimes \mathbb{R}^{p \times n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}.$$ This multiplication operation has two important properties:

  1. It is linear in both variables.
  2. It results in another rectangular matrix.

I will refer to this multiplication operation as the line product operation.

You have the transpose operation $T$ that takes an $(m \times n)$-matrix, and returns an $(n \times m)$-matrix: $$T: \mathbb{R}^{m \times n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n \times m}.$$ The transpose function satisfies the property $T \circ T(A) = A$ for any $(m \times n)$-matrix $A$.

There are two ways to describe a $d$-vector as a matrix: either as a $(d \times 1)$-matrix (a column vector), or as a $(1 \times d)$-matrix (a row vector). Let $U$ be a $(d \times 1)$-matrix and $W$ be a $(1 \times d)$-matrix. Then $P_{1}(U, V)$ is a $(d \times d)$-matrix (the outer product), and $P_{1}(V, U)$ is a scalar (the inner product).

An $n$-square matrix is an $(n \times n)$-matrix. The $n$-identity matrix $I_{n}$ is an important example of a $n$-square matrix: $$I_{n} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & \cdots & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$ The line product of two $n$-square matrices $A$ and $B$ is another $n$-square matrix. However, in general $P_{1}(A, B) \neq P_{1}(B, A)$. Indeed, the commutator function $[A, B]$ quantifies this discrepancy: $$[A, B] = P_{1}(A, B) - P_{1}(B, A).$$ The line product is noncommutative.

3-Hypermatrices

3-Hypermatrices are the next step in the ladder. These objects carry three indices and can be represented as a cuboidal array of numbers. A $(p \times q \times r)$-hypermatrix with real components is an element of $\mathbb{R}^{p \times q \times r}$.

Since a 3-hypermatrix has three indices, the line product no longer returns another 3-hypermatrix. After treating the index structure of a 3-hypermatrix as a triangle, and noticing that you can make a triangle from three other triangles, I arrived at the triangle product: $$P_{2} : \mathbb{R}^{a \times p \times q} \otimes \mathbb{R}^{p \times b \times r} \otimes \mathbb{R}^{q \times r \times c} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{a \times b \times c}.$$ In index form, $D = P_{2}(A, B, C)$ looks like $$D_{abc} = A_{apq} B_{pbr} C_{qrc}.$$ This multiplication operation shares the same two properties from above with the line product: it is linear in each of the 3-hypermatrices, and it results in another 3-hypermatrix.

Before I introduce the five transposition operations that can act on a 3-hypermatrix, it is useful to introduce two auxiliary operations: $$R: \mathbb{R}^{a \times b \times c} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{c \times a \times b}, \quad M: \mathbb{R}^{a \times b \times c} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{c \times b \times a},$$ which satisfy the properties $R \circ R \circ R(A) = A$ and $M\circ M(A) = A$ for any $(a \times b \times c)$-hypermatrix $A$. With these in hand, the five transposition operations are: $$R, \quad R \circ R, \quad M, \quad R \circ M, \quad R \circ R \circ M.$$ Together with the identity operation $I$, these six operations form the smallest nonabelian group, the dihedral group of order 6. Alternatively, you can introduce two swap operations: $$S_{12}: \mathbb{R}^{a \times b \times c} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{b \times a \times c}, \quad S_{23}: \mathbb{R}^{a \times b \times c} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{a \times c \times b}. $$ which satisfy $S_{12} \circ S_{12}(A) = A$ and $S_{23} \circ S_{23}(A) = A$. Then, the five transposition operations are $$S_{12}, \quad S_{23}, \quad S_{12} \circ S_{23}, \quad S_{23} \circ S_{12}, \quad S_{12} \circ S_{23} \circ S_{12}. $$ Note that $S_{12} \circ S_{23} = R$ and $S_{12} \circ S_{23} \circ S_{12} = M$. If the entries of the 3-hypermatrix are complex, you can enhance the transposition group by adding a complex conjugation operation $C$ and five Hermite transposition operations. Thus, the Hermite transposition group has order 12 and corresponds to the dihedral group of order 12.

There are three ways to describe a $d$-vector as a 3-hypermatrix: either as a $(d \times 1 \times 1)$-hypermatrix, as a $(1 \times d \times 1)$-hypermatrix, or as a $(1 \times 1 \times d)$-hypermatrix. Let $X$ be a $(d \times 1 \times 1)$-hypermatrix, $Y$ be a $(1 \times d \times 1)$-hypermatrix, and $Z$ be a $(1 \times 1 \times d)$-hypermatrix. Then:

  • $P_{2}(X, Y, Z)$ is a $(d \times d \times d)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the polyadic tensor $X_{a} Y_{b} Z_{c}$
  • $P_{2}(X, Z, Y)$ is a $(d \times 1 \times 1)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the vector $(Z \cdot Y) X_{a}$
  • $P_{2}(Z, Y, X)$ is a $(1 \times d \times 1)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the vector $(Z \cdot X) Y_{b}$
  • $P_{2}(Y, X, Z)$ is a $(1 \times 1 \times d)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the vector $(Y \cdot X) Z_{c}$

Note that $P_{2}(Z, X, Y)$ and $P_{2}(Y, Z, X)$ are not well-defined because of dimensional issues. If $X$ is such that the entries $X_{a}$ satisfy $X_{a}X_{a} = 1$, then $X$ satisfies the relation $P_{2}(X, X, X) = X$.

There are three ways to describe a $n$-square matrix as a 3-hypermatrix: either as a $(1 \times n \times n)$-hypermatrix, as an $(n \times 1 \times n)$-hypermatrix, or as an $(n \times n \times 1)$-hypermatrix. Let $F$ be a $(1 \times n \times n)$-hypermatrix, $G$ be a $(n \times 1 \times n)$-hypermatrix, and $H$ be a $(n \times n \times 1)$-hypermatrix. Then:

  • $P_{2}(F, G, H)$ is an $(1 \times 1 \times 1)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the scalar $\operatorname{tr}{(F G H)}$
  • $P_{2}(F, H, G)$ is an $(1 \times n \times n)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the $n$-square matrix $\operatorname{tr}{(HG)} F_{ab}$
  • $P_{2}(H, G, F)$ is an $(n \times 1 \times n)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the $n$-square matrix $\operatorname{tr}{(HF)} G_{ab}$
  • $P_{2}(G, F, H)$ is an $(n \times n \times 1)$-hypermatrix, i.e. the $n$-square matrix $\operatorname{tr}{(FG)} H_{ab}$

Note that $P_{2}(H, F, G)$ and $P_{2}(G, H, F)$ are not well-defined because of dimensional issues.

An $n$-cube 3-hypermatrix is an $(n \times n \times n)$-hypermatrix. The $n$-identity 3-hypermatrix is an important example of an $n$-cube 3-hypermatrix. The triangle product of three $n$-cube 3-hypermatrices $A$, $B$ and $C$ is another $n$-cube 3-hypermatrix.

entry.title: Tesseracts and Pentatopes
entry.summary:
Recall the factorial function $n!$ $$n! = \prod_{k = 1}^{n}k$$ and the binomial coefficients $B(n, k)$: $$B(n, k) \equiv \frac{n!}{(n - k)! k!}$$ With the binomial coefficients, you can define the $n$-th $k$-simplex number $S_{k}(n)$: $$S_{k}(n) \equiv B(n - k + 1, k)$$ When $k = 1$, you have the line numbers: $$S_{1}(n) = n$$ When $k = 2$, you have the triangle numbers: $$S_{2}(n) = \frac{n (n + 1)}{2}$$ When $k = 3$, you have the tetrahedron numbers: $$S_{3}(n) = \frac{n (n + 1)(n + 2)}{6}$$ When $k = 4$, you have the pentatope numbers: $$S_{4}(n) = \frac{n (n + 1)(n + 2)(n + 3)}{24}$$ Besides the $k$-simplex numbers, you also have the $n$-th $k$-cube number $C_{k}(n)$: $$C_{k}(n) = n^{k}$$ The cases $k = 2$, $k = 3$, and $k = 4$ are, respectively, the square, cube, and tesseract numbers. The $n$-th $k$-cube number corresponds to the number of entries in a $k$-array of size $n$. For example, a 2-array of size $n$ is an $n \times n$ square matrix. I have been thinking about $k$-simplex and $k$-cube numbers lately because I have been thinking about square matrices and cubic hypermatrices.

The $k$-volume of a $k$-cube and the $k$-volume of a $k$-simplex are related via: $$\text{vol}(C_{k}) = k! \times \text{vol}(S_{k})$$ For example, take $k = 2$. A square can be divided into two triangles with the same area. You can translate this statement into a property of square matrices. An $n \times n$ square matrix has $n^{2}$ entries (its "area"). These $n^{2}$ entries can be divided into two identical triangular domains with $S_{2}(n - 1)$ entries, and one linear domain between the two triangles with $S_{1}(n)$ entries. Thus, $$C_{2}(n) = 2 S_{2}(n - 1) + S_{1}(n)$$ Equivalently, you can absorb the interface between the two triangles into one of them, and arrive at the result that the sum of two consecutive triangle numbers is a square number: $$C_{2}(n) = S_{2}(n - 1) + S_{2}(n)$$ But here the size of each triangular domain is different.

Similarly, a cube can be divided into six tetrahedra with the same volume. You can translate this statement into a property of $n \times n \times n$ hypermatrices. An $n \times n \times n$ hypermatrix has $n^{3}$ entries (its "volume"). These entries can be divided into six identical tetrahedral domains with $S_{3}(n-2)$ entries, six identical triangular domains with $S_{2}(n-1)$ entries, and one linear domain with $S_{1}(n)$ entries. Thus, $$C_{3}(n) = 6 S_{3}(n - 2) + 6 S_{2}(n - 1) + S_{1}(n)$$ Since $$S_{3}(n+1) = S_{3}(n) + S_{2}(n+1)$$ you can absorb the interface triangular domains into the tetrahedral domains.

I tried to find the analogous result in four dimensions. Since $4! = 24$, a tesseract can be divided into 24 identical pentatopes. Thus, you can imagine that $$C_{4}(n) = 24 S_{4}(n - 3) + \ldots$$ It took me some effort to find the full result: $$C_{4}(n) = 24 S_{4}(n - 3) + 36 S_{3}(n - 2) + 14 S_{2}(n - 1) + S_{1}(n)$$ That is, you can divide a tesseract array into 24 pentatopic arrays, 36 tetrahedral arrays, 14 triangular arrays and one linear array. I found this by first writing $$C_{4}(n) = 24 S_{4}(n - 3) + a S_{3}(n - 2) + b S_{2}(n - 1) + c S_{1}(n)$$ and then solving the equation $C_{4}(n) - n^{4} = 0$. Using this technique you can also show that $$C_{5}(n) = 120 S_{5}(n - 4) + 240 S_{4}(n - 3) + 150 S_{3}(n - 2) + 30 S_{2}(n - 1) + S_{1}(n)$$ That is, you can divide a 5-cube into 120 5-simplex arrays, 240 4-simplex arrays, 150 3-simplex arrays, 30 2-simplex arrays, and one 1-simplex array.

It seems that in general, you have $$C_{k}(n) = \sum_{l = 1}^{k} {_{k}c_{l}} S_{l}(n - l + 1)$$ I wonder if there is a neat expression for $_{k}c_{l}$.

entry.title: Cross-Ratio Versus Conformal Ratio
entry.summary:
I recently learned the difference between a cross-ratio invariant and a conformal ratio invariant, thanks to this Wikipedia entry.

Cross-Ratio

The cross-ratio is a projective invariant. Given the coordinates of four points on the complex plane, the cross-ratio is defined as $$P(1, 2, 3, 4) = \frac{(z_{1} - z_{3}) (z_{2} - z_{4})}{(z_{2} - z_{3}) (z_{1} - z_{4})} .$$ It is invariant under fractional linear transformations of the form $$ z \longrightarrow \frac{a z + b}{c z + d} .$$ There is always the arbitrariness of how to define the cross-ratio. After all, there are $4! = 24$ permutations of the coordinates, so you can argue that there are 24 possible cross-ratios for a given quartet of coordinates. However, note that if you swap two pairs you again obtain the same cross-ratio. That is, $$P(1, 2, 3, 4) = P(2, 1, 4, 3) = P(3, 4, 1, 2) = P(4, 3, 2, 1) .$$ This means that the 24 permutations must split into six inequivalent classes, each with four permutations related by the above relation. Representatives of each of these six inequivalent classes are: $$P(1, 2, 3, 4) = p \quad P(1, 2, 4, 3) = \frac{1}{p} \quad P(1, 3, 4, 2) = \frac{1}{1 - p} \quad P(1, 3, 2, 4) = 1 - p \quad P(1, 4, 3, 2) = \frac{p}{1 - p} \quad P(1, 4, 2, 3) = \frac{1 - p}{p} .$$ As you can see, once the value of $p$ is given, all possible permutations are fixed, so there is really one independent cross-ratio for any given quartet of coordinates.

Conformal Ratio

A conformal ratio is a conformal invariant. Given the coordinates of four points on $D$-dimensional space, a conformal ratio is defined as $$C(1, 2, 3, 4) = \frac{(x_{1} - x_{3})^{2} (x_{2} - x_{4})^{2}}{(x_{2} - x_{3})^{2} (x_{1} - x_{4})^{2}} ,$$ where $(x_{1} - x_{3})^{2}$ means the square of the magnitude of the $D$-dimensional vector $x_{1} - x_{3}$. In some sense, after a change of basis, the cross-ratio is the square root of a conformal ratio in two dimensions.

Again you encounter the arbitrariness of which of the $4! = 24$ permutations to use for the definition of a conformal ratio. Just like the cross-ratio, you find that a conformal ratio is invariant under the exchange of two pairs of coordinates. So again you find six inequivalent classes. However, unlike the cross-ratio, you find that fixing the value of the conformal ratio for one class does not fix the other five classes: $$C(1, 2, 3, 4) = u \quad C(1, 2, 4, 3) = \frac{1}{u} \quad C(1, 3, 4, 2) = \frac{1}{v} \quad C(1, 3, 2, 4) = v \quad C(1, 4, 3, 2) = \frac{u}{v} \quad C(1, 4, 2, 3) = \frac{v}{u} .$$ Indeed, now you have two independent conformal ratios for a given quartet of coordinates.

entry.title: Points in Space
entry.summary:
Consider $N$ distinct points $P_{1}$, $P_{2}$, ..., $P_{N}$ with coordinates $x_{1}$, $x_{2}$, ..., $x_{N}$. One can draw $N^{2}$ lines connecting these $N$ points. If we ommit lines that connect a point to itself, then we have $N(N-1)/2$ possible distinct lines. Out of these, $N$ can be regarded as external lines (corresponding to the edges of a convex polygonal perimeter connecting the $N$ points) and $N(N - 3)/2$ can be regarded as internal lines (the lines inside the perimeter).

We start with $N$ distinct position variables. One can imagine making a change of variables$$(x_{1}, x_{2}, ..., x_{N}) \longrightarrow (X, x_{ij})$$where $X$ describes the center-of-mass position of the system, and the $x_{ij}$ variables represent a set of $N - 1$ independent coordinate differences $x_{ij} \equiv x_{i} - x_{j}$. One can construct more than $N - 1$ coordinate differences, but it is only possible to have $N - 1$ linearly independent ones. Indeed, one can write$$N - 1 = \frac{N(N-1)}{2} + N - 1 - \frac{N(N-1)}{2}$$which can be rewritten as$$N - 1 = \frac{N(N-1)}{2} - \frac{(N - 2)(N - 1)}{2}$$So if we want to keep all possible $N(N-1)/2$ coordinate differences available, we need to introduce $(N-2)(N-1)/2$ auxilliary variables (i.e. Lagrange multipliers) that enforce the linear constraints that leave only $N-1$ linearly-independent ones.
